qas.question: What was the estimated total value of pirated software in 2010?
Who accounted for over half the total?
What did the established markets receive for the first time?

answers.text: less PC shipments than emerging economies

qas.question: What country has the highest retail value of software?
What percentage of software in Africa is illegal?
What was the estimated total value of pirated software in 2000?
What was the known total value of pirated software in 2010?
Who accounted for less than half the total?

plausible_answers.text: less PC shipments than emerging economies

qas.question: What did the established markets receive for the last time?
What country has the lowest retail value of software?

context: The 2011 Business Software Alliance Piracy Study Standard, estimates the total commercial value of illegally copied software to be at <a0_0><b5_0><b6_0>$59 billion<b6_0/><b5_0/><a0_0/> in 2010, with <a1_0>emerging markets<a1_0/> accounting for $31.9 billion, over half of the total. Furthermore, mature markets for the first time received <a2_0><b8_0>less PC shipments than emerging economies<b8_0/><a2_0/> in 2010, making <b7_0>emerging markets<b7_0/> now responsible for more than half of all computers in use worldwide. In addition with software infringement rates of 68 percent comparing to 24 percent of mature markets, emerging markets thus possess the majority of the global increase in the commercial value of counterfeit software. <a3_0>China<a3_0/> continues to have the highest commercial value of such software at $8.9 billion among developing countries and second in the world behind the US at $9.7 billion in 2011. In 2011, the Business Software Alliance announced that <a4_0><b9_0>83 percent<b9_0/><a4_0/> of software deployed on PCs in Africa has been pirated (excluding South Africa).
